dc:description:
**DNAH10, Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (MONDO:0016575), autosomal recessive**

DNAH10 was first described as a Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD)-causing gene in 2023 (Wang et al. 2023, PMID: 37314648). The specific disease entity, Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (MONDO:0016575), OMIM:603336), is one of at least 45 different primary ciliary dyskinesias distinguished by a single monogenic cause. Some of the most common patient phenotypes are: Male infertility, Immotile sperm, Abnormal sperm morphology, Short sperm flagella, Absent sperm flagella, Coiled sperm flagella, Irregularly shaped sperm tail, Abnormal sperm motility and Abnormal sperm tail morphology. Per the recommendations of the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, the GCEP decided to split and perform separate curations for both gene-diseases entities: One curation for the relationship between DNAH10 and PCD and another one for the relationship between DNAH10 and Spermatogenic Failure 56. This curation is focused on the relationship between DNAH10 and PCD.

Twelve variants: (3 type of genetic mutation: Missense (9), Frameshift (2) and Nonsense (1) that have been reported in 8 probands in 4 publications (PMIDs: 34237282, 34657236, 37314648 and 34791246) are included in this curation. Not all of the probands were scorable for PCD.

Many of the probands sought treatment for their male infertility and were able to successfully conceive a child with their wives. The affected and fertility status of most of the siblings of the probands was unknown.

Overall, the mechanism of pathogenicity appears to be loss of function as shown by the suspected disease-causing variants in the probands. 

This gene-disease relationship is also supported by multiple forms of experimental evidence such as Expression A (Quantity: 1), Model System: Zebrafish (Quantity: 2), Model System: Trypanosoma (Quantity: 1) and Model System: Mouse (Quantity: 3). First, GTex data showed that DNAH10 is primarily expressed in the Testis, Fallopian Tube and Lung. ProteinAtlas recapitulates that by showing expression primarily in Male Tissues, Female Tissues and Respiratory System. Additionally, Maiti et al. 2000 (PMID: 11175280) shows that DNAH10 is expressed in the Brain, Testis and Trachea. The areas of expression across the GTex, ProteinAtlas and paper are consistent with PCD phenotypes. Wang et al. 2021 (PMID: 34915022) presented a Zebrafish model. Both the model and the probands had immotile cilia and the scoliosis seen in the model is similar to the phenotype of abdominal situs inversus in humans. Next, Zukas el al. 2012 contained a Trypanosoma brucei model where both the model and the probands were found to have immotile cilia. Then, Tu et al. 2021 (PMID: 34237282)  had a knockout and a knockin mouse model. The knockout model demonstrated a variety of phenotypes: Both the model and human probands displayed male infertility. The model had immotile sperm which is similar to the human phenotype of abnormal sperm motility. Additionally, the model showed abnormal sperm morphology which is similar to the abnormal sperm tail morphology found in humans. Finally, both the model and human probands displayed absent sperm flagella, coiled sperm flagella, short sperm flagella and irregularly shaped sperm tails. Wang et al. 2023 (PMID: 37314648) provided further details about the Tu et al. knockout mouse - The model had abnormal ciliary motility which is similar to the human phenotype of abnormal sperm motility and both the model and human probands displayed immotile cilia. Not only that, the model displayed airway cilia and sperm flagellar ultrastructures and mobility deficiency and also recapitulated PCD phenotypes including hydrocephalus, chronic respiratory infection, and male infertility. TEM analysis of airway epithelium cells revealed microtubular disorganization and IDA defect of the ciliary axoneme. The knockin model also demonstrated many of the phenotypes found in human probands: Both the model and human probands displayed male infertility. The model had immotile sperm which is similar to the human phenotype of abnormal sperm motility. Additionally, the model showed abnormal sperm morphology which is similar to the abnormal sperm tail morphology found in humans. Then, both the model and human probands displayed absent sperm flagella, coiled sperm flagella, short sperm flagella and irregularly shaped sperm tails. Wang et al. 2023 (PMID: 37314648) also contained a knockin model. Within the knockin model, both the model and human probands displayed immotile cilia. The model had abnormal ciliary motility which is similar to the human phenotype of abnormal sperm motility. Both the model and the patients display male infertility, oligozoospermia, absent sperm flagella, short sperm flagella, coiled sperm flagella and irregularly shaped sperm tails. Lastly, Liu et al. 2018 (PMID: 29843777), shows abnormal heart looping in DNAH10 mutation zebrafish embryos which recapitulates the laterality defects found in the human probands (Figure 3B and 3C).

In conclusion, DNAH10 has a limited association with Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia. This classification has been clearly demonstrated and confirmed through both experimental and genetic evidence and has been upheld over time. 

This classification was approved by the Motile Ciliopathy GCEP on February 13th, 2025 (SOP Version 10).

evidence.dc:description: Not a PCD proband.

Functional Evidence:

Figure 2 - Morphology of spermatozoa in a patient carrying a DNAH10 variant. A–E and F–J show haematoxylin and eosin staining and scanning electron microscopy images of the spermatozoa, respectively. A and F Typical spermatozoa from unaffected control. B and G Short flagella. C and H Absent flagella. D and I Coiled flagella. E and J Angulated flagella. Representative images of patient AY0229 are shown. Scale bars = 5 μm

Figure 3 - Expression and location of DNAH10 and DNAH1 in spermatozoa from patients and unaffected control. A Spermatozoa were stained with anti-DNAH10 (red) and anti-α-tubulin (green). B Spermatozoa were stained with anti-DNAH1 (red) and anti-α-tubulin (green). Cell nuclei were stained with DAPI. Scale bars = 5 μm

Figure 4 - Transmission electron microscopy analysis of spermatozoa obtained from patient AY0229 and an unaffected control. Most of the sperm IDA of the patient was defective (yellow arrows in enlarged figures).

evidence.rdfs:label: AY0229
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Chinese Patient AY0229 was from a consanguineous family.

evidence.dc:description: Not a PCD proband.
Not a PCD proband.

evidence.rdfs:label: P92
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Chinese Proband was diagnosed with MMAF.

evidence.dc:description: Downscored for consanguinity, upscored for functional evidence

Functional Evidence:

Figure 2: (E) Cross-sectional TEM photographs of respiratory epithelial cells from the normal control (NC) and proband. Compared with the normal 9+2 ultrastructure in the respiratory cilia of the NC, the mutant cilia of the proband showed disorganized 9+2 structure and IDA defects. DMT, doublet microtubule, indicated with green arrows; CP, central pair, indicated with blue arrows; IDA, inner dynein arm, indicated with red arrow; ODA, outer dynein arm, indicated with yellow arrows. Scale bars, 50 nm. (F) TEM analysis of cilia microtubular organization. Airway ciliary microtubular disorganization was observed in 66% of the cross sections (n=68) of the proband, which is remarkably more than that of the NC (n=78). (G) TEM analysis of ciliary IDA defect. Airway ciliary IDA defect was observed in 99% of the cross sections (n=68) of the proband, which is considerably more than that of the NC (n=78).

(H) Papanicolaou staining for spermatozoa of the proband showed sparse sperms and absent, short, coiled, or irregular flagella compared with the NC. Scale bars, 5 μm. (I) Cross-sectional TEM photographs of sperm flagella from the NC and proband. Compared with the normal 9+2 ultrastructure in the sperm flagellum of the NC, the mutant flagellum of the proband showed a disorganized 9+2 structure. DMT, doublet microtubules, indicated with green arrows; CP, central pair, indicated with blue arrow; IDA, inner dynein arm, indicated with red arrow; ODA, outer dynein arms, indicated with yellow arrow. Scale bars, 50 nm. (J) TEM analysis of flagellar microtubular organization. Sperm flagellar microtubular disorganization was observed in 98% of the cross sections (n=60) of the proband, which is remarkably more than that of the NC (n=63). (K) TEM analysis of flagellar IDA defect. Sperm flagellar IDA defect was observed in all the cross sections (n=60) of the proband, which was considerably more than that of the NC (n=63). DNAH10 deficiency causes primary ciliary dyskinesia.

evidence.rdfs:label: 28-year-old man
evidence.detectionMethod: WES, PCD or PCD-candidate gene panel and Sanger sequencing.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
The Chinese proband was diagnosed with PCD with microtubular disorganization and IDA defects from a Chinese consanguineous family.

High-resolution computed tomography of the paranasal sinuses, chest, and abdomen of the proband revealed chronic rhinosinusitis (Fig. 1B), bronchiectasis, dextrocardia (Fig. 1C), and abdominal situs inversus (Fig. 1D).

TEM analysis of respiratory cilia revealed disorganized 9+2 structure and IDA defects (Fig. 1E–1G). Routine semen analysis of the spermatozoa of the proband revealed severe asthenoteratozoospermia with completely immotile spermatozoa and a compara- tively low sperm count. Papanicolaou staining of the proband revealed that most spermatozoa manifested absent, short, bent, and coiled flagella (Fig. 1H, Table S3). Similarly, TEM results showed a highly disorganized 9+2 structure and IDA defects in the mutant sperm flagella of the proband (Fig. 1I–1K). In summary, the proband presented complex PCD phenotypes, including sinusitis, bronchiectasis, situs inversus, and asthenoteratozoospermia.

Functional Evidence:

Figure 3: DNAH10 was localized along the sperm flagella in the sperm obtained from the NC but was almost absent in the sperm flagella in the sperm obtained from men harboring bi-allelic DNAH10 variants.

TEM analysis to observe the sperm flagellar ultrastructure of the proband.

evidence.rdfs:label: T012 II-2
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: The Chinese proband comes from a consanguineous family.

evidence.dc:description: Not a PCD proband.

Functional Evidence: Figure 2A - H&E staining for the spermatozoa obtained from a fertile control individual (NC) and men harboring bi-allelic DNAH10 variants. Compared to the spermatozoa of NC, which presented long, smooth tails (i), most spermatozoa obtained from men harboring DNAH10 variants displayed typical MMAF phenotypes, such as short (ii), absent (iii), coiled (iv), and irregular flagella (v). The data of H049 II-2 are shown as an example. Scale bars, 5 μm.

Figure 2B - (B) SEM analysis of the spermatozoa obtained from a fertile control individual (NC) and men harboring bi-allelic DNAH10 variants. (i) Normal morphology of the spermatozoon from a healthy control male. (ii–vii) Most spermatozoa obtained from men harboring bi-allelic DNAH10 variants displayed typical MMAF phenotypes, including short (ii), absent (iii), bent (iv), coiled (v), and irregular flagella (vi and vii). The data of H049 II-2 are shown as an example. Scale bars, 5 μm.
Not a PCD proband.
